channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: U.S. sends aircraft carrier to South America in major escalation of military firepower
item.description: The deployment and the quickening pace of U.S. strikes, including one Friday, raised new speculation about how far the Trump administration may go in operations it says are targeted at drug trafficking.
item.content:encoded:
The deployment and the quickening pace of U.S. strikes, including one Friday, raised new speculation about how far the Trump administration may go in operations it says are targeted at drug trafficking.

(Image credit: Evan Vucci)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: DOJ hires immigration judges after months of layoffs
item.description: Judges will soon take the bench across 16 states, the Justice Department said. These include courts that saw the biggest losses of judges this year.
item.content:encoded:
Judges will soon take the bench across 16 states, the Justice Department said. These include courts that saw the biggest losses of judges this year.

(Image credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Ximena Bustillo

item.title: Pakistan bans hard-line Islamist party known for its fierce anti-blasphemy stance
item.description: Pakistan banned a hard-line Islamist party on Thursday, more than a week after heated clashes with police that left at least five people dead.
item.content:encoded:
Pakistan banned a hard-line Islamist party on Thursday, more than a week after heated clashes with police that left at least five people dead.

(Image credit: Arif Ali)
item.dc:creator: Betsy Joles

item.title: U.S. imposes sanctions on Colombia's president and family over drug trade allegations
item.description: The sanctions sharply escalate tensions with the leftist leader of a country that has traditionally been one of the closest U.S. allies in South America.
item.content:encoded:
The sanctions sharply escalate tensions with the leftist leader of a country that has traditionally been one of the closest U.S. allies in South America.

(Image credit: Fernando Vergara)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Coffee-driven deforestation is making it harder to grow coffee, watchdog group says
item.description: In Brazil's coffee-producing areas, more than 42,000 square miles of forest have disappeared over about two decades, says Coffee Watch. Deforestation leads to drought, which harms crop yields.
item.content:encoded:
In Brazil's coffee-producing areas, more than 42,000 square miles of forest have disappeared over about two decades, says Coffee Watch. Deforestation leads to drought, which harms crop yields.

(Image credit: Evaristo Sa)
item.dc:creator: James Doubek

item.title: It's been a rollercoaster few years for Six Flags. Can Travis Kelce help?
item.description: Travis Kelce is teaming up with activist investors in hopes of transforming the embattled theme park operator Six Flags. No word yet on a Taylor Swift-themed rollercoaster.
item.content:encoded:
Travis Kelce is teaming up with activist investors in hopes of transforming the embattled theme park operator Six Flags. No word yet on a Taylor Swift-themed rollercoaster.

(Image credit: Reed Hoffmann)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: The federal government is still shut down. Here's what that means across the country
item.description: The federal government shutdown continues. Republicans and Democrats appear no closer to an agreement to end it. Many federal workers are missing full paychecks and don't know when they will resume.
item.content:encoded:
The federal government shutdown continues. Republicans and Democrats appear no closer to an agreement to end it. Many federal workers are missing full paychecks and don't know when they will resume.

(Image credit: Martin do Nascimento)
item.dc:creator: The NPR Network

item.title: Some viruses can play a deadly game of hide and seek inside the human body
item.description: Ebola is one of the nasty viruses that can hide in the body even after a patient recovers and tests negative. It can reemerge and trigger a new outbreak years later. How do they survive? And how can they be kayoed?
item.content:encoded: Ebola is one of the nasty viruses that can hide in the body even after a patient recovers and tests negative. It can reemerge and trigger a new outbreak years later. How do they survive? And how can they be kayoed?
item.dc:creator: Gabrielle Emanuel

item.title: Argentina's President Milei, a Trump ally, faces a reckoning in midterm elections
item.description: Argentina's libertarian president, Javier Milei, faces midterms amid economic chaos and a $20 billion lifeline offer from President Trump.
item.content:encoded:
Argentina's libertarian president, Javier Milei, faces midterms amid economic chaos and a $20 billion lifeline offer from President Trump.

(Image credit: Rodrigo Abd)
item.dc:creator: Natalie Alcoba

item.title: What killed Napoleon's army? Scientists find clues in DNA from fallen soldiers' teeth
item.description: In 1812, hundreds of thousands of men in Napoleon's army perished during their retreat from Russia. Researchers now believe a couple of unexpected pathogens may have helped hasten the soldiers' demise.
item.content:encoded:
In 1812, hundreds of thousands of men in Napoleon's army perished during their retreat from Russia. Researchers now believe a couple of unexpected pathogens may have helped hasten the soldiers' demise.

(Image credit: Michel Signoli / UMR 6578 Aix-Marseille Université, CNRS, EFS)
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel
